Author: Smedley#8094
Content: Is there any examples of utilizing the rpc calls from a website? Does the end user need to have agama open and the chain running on native mode for the rpc calls to run?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Smedley that is a security issue, which is why many things are designed to prevent a website from talking to your local wallet. Otherwise, random websites could steal your money. This kind of bug has happened before

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: older versions of Electrum had a bug that let evil websites talk to your local wallet and potentially steal funds, and definitely lose privacy/etc

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Smedley if you are looking to call RPCs from node/Javascript (for instance, from a native Electron app), this might help: https://github.com/MyHush/hush-ng/blob/master/src/renderer/store/index.js#L360

Author: Smedley#8094
Content: @dukeleto Thanks for the resources and explanation. So currently making a dapp on a website is not a possibility?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: You can do it sure

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I've been thinking of something just like that for #kmdlabs. There are plentybof RPC calls that don't have anything to do with funds, and a node with its wallet disabled should be fine for that type of thing, but it depends what u want to do.

Author: Smedley#8094
Content: Would assets contract potentially work?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: You would need to be able to create al the transactions locally on your website

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: When I mean it cannot use a wallet .... I kind of mean that the deamon litteralyl has no wallet compiled in.

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: The are probably other ways to do it ... but apart from creating all the transacions with some java script library locally and using SPV or something to send th eraw hex to the blockchain ... I'm not sure it can be done . The other way is something like @smk762 -  dracocanis ominator 's DragonHound... Its due for a pre release soon so show what he has been able to accomplish. This projec uses 1 central server, and "logins" for multiple "users" to post GPS locations to the blockchain. Started out to track his exacaping dog but realy has evolved into something quite awesome, that ca be used to stro any sensor data on the blockchain.

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content:
``from __future__ import print_function
import requests, json , platform, re
rpcPort = 30177
rpcUser = 'UserName'
rpcPassword = 'Password'
serverURL = 'http://' + rpcUser + ':' + rpcPassword + '@127.0.0.1:' + str(rpcPort)
payload = json.dumps({"jsonrpc": "1.0",
        "id": "python",
        "method": "getinfo",
        "params": []})
try:
    response = requests.post(serverURL, data=json.dumps(payload), auth = None)
    print(response)
except Exception as e:
    raise Exception("Couldn't connect to " + serverURL + ": ", e)``

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
@SuSC135  Is it work by curl?
```curl --user myrpcuser:myrpcpassword --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id":"curltest", "method": "getinfo", "params": [] }' -H 'content-type: text/plain;' http://127.0.0.1:myrpcport/```

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Maybe `rpcallowip` param is missing in `.conf` for your assetchain

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: it should be `rpcallowip=127.0.0.1` if you want to make RPC calls from localhost

Author: TonyL#3577

Author: TonyL#3577

Author: SuSC135#6248

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Oh, thats where is the clue

Author: SuSC135#6248
Content: Should i include the name of my asset chain or txid somewhere?

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: username/password for assetchain connection store in /.komodo/%assetchainname%/%assetchainname%.conf

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: So there should be the folder with your assetchain name in same folder with `komodo.conf`

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: And inside this folder `assetchainname.conf` which defines connection params to your assetchain daemon

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: So you need to allow rpc connections in this assetchain config, restart assetchain daemon and try again your RPC calls with username/password same as in `assetchainname.conf`
